case_data.name: Madison McPherson v. Jurupa Unified School District
case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiffs are three current and former female athletes at Jurupa Valley High School.
case_data.summary:
[This summary is temporary while we research the case.]

On September 9, 2025, Plaintiffs allege that Defendants have knowingly permitted a male student to compete on the JVHS varsity girls’ track and field and volleyball teams, access female locker rooms and bathrooms, and engage in harassing conduct toward female athletes. As a result of Defendants’ actions, Plaintiffs claim they have suffered sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, unsafe and unfair athletic environments, viewpoint discrimination, and infringements on their religious liberty and safety. These actions have deprived them of equal opportunities and their civil rights guaranteed by Title IX, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, and the First Amendment.

This case is ongoing.

22 INTRODUCTION
23 1. This lawsuit seeks to protect the rights of female student-athletes who have been
24 deprived of equal educational opportunities and athletic participation by the California Department 
25 of Education (“CDE”), the California Interscholastic Federation (“CIF”), and Jurupa Unified School 
26 District (“District” or “JUSD”). 
27
28
1
VERIFIED COMPLAINT

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 2 of 51   Page ID #:2
1 2. Plaintiffs are three current and former female athletes at Jurupa Valley High School
2 (“JVHS”). Defendants have knowingly permitted a male1 student to compete on the JVHS varsity
3 girls’ track and field and volleyball teams, access female locker rooms and bathrooms, and engage 
4 in harassing conduct toward female athletes.
5 3. As a result of Defendants’ actions, Plaintiffs have suffered sex discrimination, 
6 including sexual harassment, unsafe and unfair athletic environments, viewpoint discrimination, and 
7 infringements on their religious liberty and safety. These actions have deprived them of equal 
8 opportunities and their civil rights guaranteed by Title IX, the Equal Protection Clause of the 
9 Fourteenth Amendment, and the First Amendment.
10 4. When Plaintiffs A.M. and H.H. most recently informed their coach that they were 
11 uncomfortable sharing the volleyball court and locker room with a male student, the coach retaliated 
12 by removing them from team group chats and communications, and telling one of the girls, “If you 
13 want to be a captain and a member of our team, then be one.”
14 5. Plaintiffs have been intimidated by an intentionally hostile environment created by 
15 Defendants wherein they were bullied by school officials to censor their objections to competing 
16 with, and against, a male and to sharing intimate and private spaces with a male. 
17 6.  As recognized by California Governor Gavin Newsom in 2025, it is “deeply unfair” 
18 unfair for girls to compete against boys.2
19
20
21
22 1 “Male,” “Female, “Boy,” and “Girl” used in this Complaint refer solely to binary, biological sex and not a person’s 
“gender identity.” See Adams by & through Kasper v. Sch. Bd. of St. Johns Cnty., 57 F.4th 791, 812 (11th Cir. 2022) 
23 (Title IX defines “sex” “based on biology and reproductive function.”); Black’s Law Dictionary (5th ed. 1979) (“Sex. 
The sum of the peculiarities of structure and function that distinguish a male from a female organism[.]”); see also 
24 Bostock v. Clayton Cnty., Ga., 590 U.S. 644, 655 (2020) (“Sex” in the Civil Rights Act of 1964 “refer[s] only to 
biological distinctions between male and female”); see also Executive Order No. 14168, “Defending Women From 
25 Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government” (2025) (“‘Sex’ shall refer to 
an individual’s immutable biological classification as either male or female. ‘Sex’ is not a synonym for and does not 
26 include the concept of ‘gender identity.’”).

1 STATEMENT OF FACTS
2 A. PLAINTIFFS’ BACKGROUND
3 i. Plaintiffs’ Athletic and Academic Background
4 24. Plaintiffs McPherson, A.M., and H.H. are avid athletes and have dedicated their lives 
5 to high level athletic competition.
6 25. McPherson is a formerJurupa Valley High School(“JVHS”)multi-sport athlete who 
7 participated in varsity track and field, soccer, and volleyball. She currently competes as a collegiate 
8 volleyball player.
9 26. As a high school freshman, McPherson played both club and varsity high school 
10 soccer, while also joining a club volleyball program. 
11 27. During her high school sophomore year, McPherson played varsity volleyball, 
12 varsity soccer, and varsity track and field. She served as captain of her volleyball team and 
13 distinguished herself by earning several awards, including Volleyball Offensive MVP All-League, 
14 Soccer League Champion, and multiple All-Academic Awards.
15 28.  As a high school junior, McPherson served as captain of the girls’ varsity volleyball 
16 team. Under her leadership, the team won a League Championship and the CIF Southern Section 
17 Division 8 Title. McPherson was named League MVP and Athlete of the Month and received an 
18 All-Academic Award. She also continued to compete in varsity soccer and varsity track and field, 
19 where she earned additional awards and recognition. 
20 29. As a high school senior, McPherson maintained her leadership role in volleyball as 
21 varsity captain and continued to play on the varsity soccer team. She continued to receive various 
22 awards, including volleyball All League MVP, Athlete of the Month (8/2023), and multiple All-
23 Academic Awards across volleyball and soccer. 
24 30. In addition to her athletic skill, McPherson excelled academically, maintaining a 
25 cumulative GPA of 4.0.
26 31. McPherson’s younger sister, Plaintiff A.M., is also a multi-sport athlete at JVHS, 
27 competing in varsity volleyball, varsity soccer, and track and field. She is currently a senior at JVHS. 
28
5

24 39. In her sophomore year, H.H. joined varsity volleyball, where she contributed to the 
25 team winning the League Championship and earned All-Academic honors. The team advanced to

28
6

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 7 of 51   Page ID #:7
1 40. During her junior year, H.H. continued to excel in volleyball and track and field. She 
2 helped  the  varsity  volleyball  team  win  the  League  Championship  and  earned  All-Academic 
3 recognition. In track and field, H.H. competed at the varsity level, again earning All-Academic 
4 honors and consistently placing in competitions.
5 41. In her senior year, H.H. remains an active member of the varsity volleyball team as 
6 a starter and will again be competing in track and field in the upcoming track and field season. 
7 42. In addition to her athletic skill, H.H. has excelled academically, maintaining a 
8 cumulative GPA of 4.3.
9 ii. Plaintiffs’ Religious Background
10 43. Plaintiffs Munoz, McPherson, and A.M. are practicing Catholics who believe that 
11 God created human beings as male and female and that gender is a fixed characteristic that cannot 
12 be changed. Their faith informs their understanding of human identity and shapes their views 
13 regarding the importance of recognizing and honoring the distinctives of male and female as created 
14 by God.
15 44.  Plaintiffs Hazameh and H.H. are practicing Muslims whose religious obligations 
16 prevent H.H. from exposing her hair or body to males, including by wearing a hijab. Guided by 
17 Islamic teachings, they believe that men and women have distinct biological differences, roles, and 
18 responsibilities, which should be respected and upheld. Their faith emphasizes modesty, dignity, 
19 and the honoring of gender distinctions which must conform with one’ biological sex in both 
20 practice and identity.
21 45. Based on these sincerely held religious beliefs, Plaintiffs McPherson, A.M., and H.H. 
22 object to sharing locker rooms with members of the opposite sex and to participating on athletic 
23 teams that include members of the opposite sex. Plaintiffs also object to any inappropriate and 
24 unwelcomed physical contact with males. 
25 46. Based on their sincerely held religious beliefs, Plaintiffs Hazameh and Munoz also 
26 object to their daughters being required to share locker rooms or teams with males and inappropriate 
27 physical contact with males. 
28
7
VERIFIED COMPLAINT

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 8 of 51   Page ID #:8
1 47. Due to fear and intimidation caused by school administrators, Plaintiffs have felt 
2 intimidated, silenced. and unable to state their religious objections.  
3 B. SCOPE OF TITLE IX
4 48. Congress enacted Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, 20 U.S.C. § 1681, 
5 to  prohibit  sex-based  discrimination  in  federally  funded  education  programs.  Section  901(a) 
6 provides: “No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation 
7 in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or 
8 activity receiving Federal financial assistance.”
9 49. Title IX was designed to eliminate significant “discrimination against women in 
10 education” and to ensure that biological women received “equal opportunity to aspire, achieve, 
11 participate in and contribute to society based on their individual talents and capacities.” See Neal v. 
12 Bd. of Trs. of Cal. State Univs., 198 F.3d 763, 766 (9th Cir. 1999); United States v. Virginia, 518 
13 U.S. 515, 532 (1996).
14 50. Title IX was adopted in response to widespread educational discrimination against 
15 women, particularly in admissions and faculty employment. See H.R. Rep. No. 92-554, at 51–52; 
16 116 Cong. Rec. 6398–6400. 
17 51.  In the hearings on equal rights, Dr. Bernice Sandler called for protections for women 
18 in education because, “Sex prejudice is so ingrained in our society that many who practice it are 
19 simply unaware that they are hurting women. Let me reiterate, –it is the last socially acceptable 
20 prejudice.” Hearings, Ninety-first Congress, second session, on S.J. Res. 61, May 5, 6, and 7, 1970, 
21 p. 415.
22 52.  Senator  Birch  Bayh, Title  IX’s  chief  sponsor, stated  the  bill  was  designed  to 
23 “guarantee that women, too, enjoy the educational opportunity every American deserves.” 117 
24 Cong. Rec. 32,476–79; 118 Cong. Rec. 5808 (1972). 
25 53.  Senator Bayh further stressed that Title IX “provide[d] equal access to women and 
26 men” but did not “desegregate” spaces and activities that have long been sex-separated. 117 Cong. 
27 Rec.  30407  (1971).  Senator  Bayh recognized  that  regulations  would  be  necessary  to  “allow 
28
8
VERIFIED COMPLAINT

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 9 of 51   Page ID #:9
1 enforcing agencies to permit differential treatment by sex only, . . . such as . . . in sports facilities or 
2 other instances where personal privacy must be preserved.”118 Cong. Rec. 5807.
3 54. Title IX does have exemptions that allow for traditionally male-only and female-only 
4 activities, so long as similar opportunities are permitted for the opposite sex. See 20 U.S.C. § 1686; 
5 34 C.F.R. §§ 106.33, 106.41(b).1. 
6 55. Under Title IX, “sex, like race and national origin, is an immutable characteristic 
7 determined solely by” biology. Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U.S. 677, 686 (1973) (plurality 
8 opinion). 
9 56. As a whole, biological males have physiological advantages over biological females. 
10 See Clarkv. Arizona Interscholastic Ass’n, 695 F.2d 1126, 1131 (9th Cir. 1982) (“The record makes 
11 clear that due to average physiological differences, males would displace females to a substantial 
12 extent  if  they  were  allowed  to  compete  for  positions  on  the  volleyball  team. Thus,  athletic 
13 opportunities for women would be diminished.”); Cape v. Tennesee Secondary School Athletic 
14 Ass’n, 563 F.2d 793, 795 (6th Cir. 1977) (overturned on other grounds) (“It takes little imagination 
15 to realize that were play and competition not separated by sex, the great bulk of the females would 
16 quickly  be  eliminated  from  participation  and  denied  any  meaningful  opportunity  for  athletic 
17 involvement.”). 
18 57.  Scientific  research  demonstrates  that  biological  males,  on  average,  possess 
19 significant physiological advantages over biological females, including greater height and body 
20 mass, larger and stronger muscles and bones, increased lung capacity, and higher cardiac output. 
21 While these advantages are greatest after puberty, they begin at birth. See, e.g., Frank Falkner, J.M. 
22 Tanner, Human Growth: Postnatal Growth, p. 286 (1976) (“Boys demonstrate, on the average, 
23 greater strength than girls at all ages.”). 
24 58.  As Justice Stevens put it, “[w]ithout a gender–based classification in competitive 
25 contact sports, there would be a substantial risk that boys would dominate the girls’ programs and 
26 deny them an equal opportunity to compete in interscholastic events.” O’Connor v. Bd. of Ed. of 
27 Sch. Dist. 23, 449 U.S. 1301, 1307 (1980) (Stevens, J., in chambers). 
28
9
VERIFIED COMPLAINT

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 10 of 51   Page ID
#:10
1 59. At the time of Title IX’s enactment, the dictionary definitions of “sex” demonstrate 
2 that Congress meant biological sex when it prohibited discrimination on the basis of “sex” in 
3 education. See Adams v. Schl. Bd. of St. Johns Cty., 58 F.4th 791 (2022) (citingSex, American
4 Heritage Dictionary of the English Language (1976) (“The property or quality by which organisms are 
5 classified according to their reproductive functions.”); Sex, American Heritage Dictionary of the English 
6 Language (1979) (same);Sex, Female, Male, Oxford English Dictionary (re-issue ed. 1978) (defining 
7 “sex” as “[e]ither of the two divisions of organic beings distinguished as male and female respectively,” 
8 “female” as “[b]elonging to the sex which bears offspring,” and “male” as “[o]f or belonging to the sex 
9 which begets offspring, or performs the fecundating function of generation”); Sex, Webster's New 
10 World Dictionary (1972) (“[E]ither of the two divisions, male or female, into which persons, animals, 
11 or plants are divided, with reference to their reproductive functions.”); Sex, Female, Male, Webster's 
12 Seventh New Collegiate Dictionary (1969) (defining “sex” as “either of two divisions of organisms 
13 distinguished respectively as male or female,” “female” as “an individual that bears young or produces 
14 eggs as distinguished from one that begets young,” and “male” as “of, relating to, or being the sex that 
15 begets young by performing the fertilizing function”); Sex, Random House College Dictionary (rev. ed. 
16 1980) (“[E]ither the male or female division of a species, esp. as differentiated with reference to the 
17 reproductive functions.”). 
18 60.  The  Department  of  Health,  Education  and  Welfare  (the  predecessor  to  the 
19 Department of Education) issued regulations for Title IX that took effect in 1975. See 34 C.F.R. § § 
20 106.1-106.82. 
21 61.  These regulations required that, if an entity subject to Title IX provides athletic 
22 programs or opportunities separated by sex, then it must do so in a manner that “provide[s] equal 
23 athletic opportunity for members of both sexes.” 34 C.F.R. § 106.41(c). 
24 62.  Equal athletic opportunity can be determined by whether such athletic opportunities 
25 “effectively accommodate the interests and abilities of both sexes.” 34 C.F.R. § 106.41(c).  
26 63.  Here, the “governing principle” is that “the athletic interests and abilities of male and 
27 female students must be equally effectively accommodated.” Policy Interpretation, 44 Fed. Reg. 
28 71,413, 71,414 (1979). 
10 
VERIFIED COMPLAINT

Case 5:25-cv-02362-CAS-SP     Document 1     Filed 09/09/25     Page 11 of 51   Page ID
#:11
1 64. More specifically, the District must accommodate the physical abilities of girls “to 
2 the extent necessary to provide equal opportunity in . . . levels of competition,” and competitive 
3 opportunities “which equally reflect their abilities.” Policy Interpretation, 44 Fed. Reg. at 71,417-
4 418.
5 65. As  another  aspect  of  equal  athletic  opportunity,  implementing  regulations  and 
6 guidance state that male and female athletes “should receive equivalent treatment, benefits and 
7 opportunities.” Policy Interpretation, 44 Fed. Reg. at 71,415. 
8 66. The “equal treatment” to which girls are entitled includes equal “opportunities to 
9 engage in . . . post-season competition,” id.at 71,416, equal opportunities for public recognition, 34 
10 C.F.R. § 106.41(c), and the right to be free of any policies which are “discriminatory in . . . effect” 
11 or that have the effect of denying “equality of athletic opportunity.” 44 Fed. Reg. at 71,417.
12 67. An institution is only in compliance “if the compared program components are 
13 equivalent, that is, equal or equal in effect.” Id. at 71,415.
14 68. Accordingly, Title IX is understood to require the allocation of equal opportunities 
15 based on biological sex alone without regard to or consideration of gender identity. When an 
16 institution creates a team for one sex, “it must do so for members of the other sex” given certain 
17 conditions are met. Id.  
18 69.  In 2024, the Biden administration issued provisions aimed at expanding Title IX. The 
19 new regulations stated that Title IX forbids discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender 
20 identity.
21 70. On  January  9,  2025,  a  federal  judge  invalidated  the  Biden  administration’s 
22 regulations citing several legal flaws, including that the United States Education Department 
23 exceeded its authority by expanding the scope of Title IX. Tennessee v. Cardona, No. CV 2:24-072-
24 DCR, 2025 WL 63795 (E.D. Ky. Jan. 9, 2025), as amended (Jan. 10, 2025).
25 71. On  January  20,  2025,  President  Donald  Trump  issued  an  Executive  Order 
26 “Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the
